concept.title: Demo Self Service Xref and Publish

li.p: Teresa has created a GitHub repository layout for the Oxygen Workshop.

fig.title: Teresa's Oxygen Workshop GitHub repository layout.

li.p: The repository contains a csv file describing the students taking the course

fig.title: The details of the students taking the course.

li.p: The repository contains a template folder which describes the layout of each students work area. Phil has written a Perl program that copies this template folder into each student's work area.

fig.title: Template folder to copy to each student.

li.p: The Workshop repository showing the student work books - that is - the documents that each student will modify during the course.

fig.title: Student work books.

li.p: Each of the student's book maps can be personalized.

fig.title: Personalized Student map.

li.p: Phil has created a GitHub repository with a copy of the Student's work files. A working repository is a good idea because it stops the students inadvertently damaging our master copy as held in Teresa's repo.

fig.title: Phil's version of Teresa's workshop repo.

li.p: Phil's version of the repo also holds a copy of the source for the document: "Self Service Xref and Publish". This document is written as a Dita Task. We have access to an excellent example of a Dita Concept in the GB Standard which I believe Bill has written up. It would not be difficult to format a reference topic from Data::Edit::Xml. These documents, if worked up a little further, would make useful examples of the major Dita topic formats.

fig.title: Phil's version of Teresa's workshop repo showing addition of Xref.xml

li.p: Each student gets a complete copy of the document "Self Service Xref and Publish". Lets see what happens if we run Data::Edit::Xml::Xref against these files.

fig.title: Phil's version of Teresa's workshop repo showing a screenshot in the student's work area.

li.p: First we start a spot instance of the right size on AWS and make a copy of its IP address.

fig.title: Get the IP address of the spot instance.

li.p: We enter the IP address into any browser to reach the web server embedded in the spot instance and navigate to the page where we can enter the url of the GitHub repository we wish to Data::Edit::Xml::Xref .

fig.title: Spot instance web server home page.

li.p: Once we have entered the url of our GitHub repository we can press the start button to start the conversion.

fig.title: Ready to Enter GitHub repo name into web site.

li.p: As you an see, Data::Edit::Xml::Xref is ready to run.

fig.title: Web site with repo entered and ready to start.

li.p: When the conversion starts it displays the current processing status of the conversion via a log of the actions performed and by the process status.

fig.title: Conversion started.

li.p: Press the Refresh button to see the latest conversion status.

fig.title: Conversion running.

li.p: When the conversion has completed the results are zipped into a file which can be downloaded.

fig.title: Conversion results zip file.

li.p: The results zip folder contains some well known folders.

fig.title: Overview of downloaded results zip file.

li.p: In particular the out/ folder contains the results of flattening all the images and xml files. If, as in this case, the students have yet to make any changes, then a considerable amount of flattening is possible and as can be seen in this screenshot.

fig.title: Flattened files in folder out/ of results zip file.

li.p: The publications/

fig.title: Each map published as PDF

li.p: Now lets turn out attention to how we actually write Dita xml. Please create an empty file. Type the letter c for concept and press tab to get an empty concept.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Create concept.

li.p: Fill in the title of the concept.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Add title.

li.p: Use the same technique to create an ordered list. Type olllll and press tab to create an ordered list with five items in it.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Create first ol.

li.p: Create a second similar ordered list using ollllL.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Create second ol.

li.p: Now we have two lists and would like to merge them into one list.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Create second ol result.

li.p: To perform an action on an xml node, type a function name from Data::Edit::Xml against the closing angle bracket and press Execute

fig.title: Edit Xml - Start mlp.

li.p: The two lists are merged into one.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Finish mlp.

li.p: The actions performed are recorded in a log file whise data can be used to drive other processes.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Finish mlp and show log.

li.p: There are many other such actions available, such as rrrr which repeats a node 4 times.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Start repeat 4 times.

li.p: The results of repeating a node 4 times. If you start to type an action code, Geany will prompt you with the possibilities.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Repeat 4 times results.

li.p: You can also select one or a range of nodes by marking them with ss for start selecyion and se for selection end.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Set selection start.

li.p: Once a selection has been made you can move the selection after ma or before mb another node.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Move selection after tag results.

li.p: The results of performing a move after on the selected nodes.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Selection moved with log.

li.p: It is easy to expand links to well known urls. Simply type L[shortname] and press Execute.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Ready to expand a link.

li.p: Data::Edit::Xml contains many useful functions that can be placed against nodes to transform them. For instance to convert a Dita Concept to a Dita Task ct against the closing angle bracket of the Dita Concept and press Execute.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Link expanded. Start conversion to task.

li.p: Using the programmed capabilities in Data::Edit::Xml saves a lot of manual labor. Ryffine will be pleased to add similar capabilities to assist you in your work.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Concept converted to task with log showing.

li.p: Another such example is cr which creates a report showing the numerosity of each type of tag under the specified node.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Count tags report start.

li.p: The tag count report shows up in the log after you have hit Execute.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Tags count report in log file.

li.p: As a final illustration, try using ck to change the tags of the immediate children of a specified node.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Change kids start.

li.p: There again, perhaps not. Just apply undo to remove the unwanted changes.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Change kids end.

li.p: To validate your Xml press F8.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Validation error in Xml

li.p: To publish your XML as PDF press F9.

fig.title: Edit Xml - Publish to PDF.
